Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Lay Theories of Creativity: How beliefs about the malleability of creativity influence creativ

POR.DRECONTENT:
Creativity and innovation are highly sought attributes in today’s business world.  Yet for organizations looking to increase innovation, seeking the most creative people is only half the equation. Maximizing the creativity one is capable of is the other half. But in order to maximize anything, one must believe there is an ability to improve - something that can be maximized.

      Much previous psychological work demonstrates the integral role expectations play in the manifestation of various attributes. In this research, we examined beliefs toward creativity and examined the influence these beliefs have on various assessments of the creative process. We suspected people who view creativity as fixed (entity beliefs) are less likely to engage in a lengthy creative process, as they are less open to the critical feedback and potential “microfailures” systemic to the creative process. Incremental theorists, who instead believe that traits and attributes are subject to change and can be increased through effort, should be more accepting of feedback and more willing to endure the entire creative process. This NSF funding allowed us to assess the relationship these creativity beliefs have with lifetime creative achievement in Japanese citizens.

     Across a series of studies on this topic, we find that entity beliefs of creativity are associated with less creative production during the lifespan and with less creative problem-solving. We find similar results in our Japanese samples as in our American samples. Experimental messages priming incremental thinking about creativity lead to more original creative problem-solving. Our data suggests that statements from managers, teachers, peers, parents and others that advocate incremental thinking about creativity may be enough to at least temporarily increase creative output in others. Previous intervention studies show that introducing incremental belief mindsets has persistent and stable benefits. Considering the ever-growing value placed on creativity and innovation in our society, the present research offers a simple method for facilitating creativity.
